indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

healthRecommendations: Pollen levels are very low right now. It's a great day to enjoy the outdoors!

indexInfo.indexDescription: Many people with allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms. Very sensitive people may experience severe symptoms

healthRecommendations: Avoid mowing the lawn and raking leaves.
When driving the car, close your windows and turn the air conditioning system to recirculation mode.
Keep your windows closed and turn on your air purifier or air conditioning.
Consider staying indoors during the peak pollen hours (morning and early afternoon).

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialColors: Leaves are golden, orange, red, and pink.
plantDescription.specialShapes: Forked trunk. The leaves are oppositely arranged, usually palmate and lobed, but can also be pinnately compound or trifoliate, with a smooth or serrated margin.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Plane tree pollen.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.season: Two distinct seasons, late winter to early spring, and late summer to fall (species dependent)
plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are alternate, obovate with a pointed tip, usually a lopsided base, and serrated margins.
plantDescription.crossReaction: There is no known cross-allergies related to elm.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialColors: The bark is yellowish-green and smooth on young trees but grayish-brown and deeply furrowed with scaly ridges in maturity.
plantDescription.specialShapes: Cottonwood leaves are alternate and triangular. The trees produce white seeds that look like cotton. These seeds appear after the pollen season.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Birch, Oak, Hazel or Alder.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are usually opposite and pinnately compound with an odd number of leaflets. Ash trees produce `helicopter seeds`.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Olive and Privet pollen.

indexInfo.indexDescription: Pollen levels are very low and are not likely to trigger allergic reactions

plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are green needles.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Spruce, Hemlock and Fir pollen.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialColors: The bark color of oaks ranges from whitish-gray to dark, almost black.
plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are alternate and usually lobed with smooth or spiny margins. The fruits are acorns, oval-shaped seeds in a cupped structure named cupule.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Alder, Birch, Hazel, Hornbeam, and Beech pollen.

indexInfo.indexDescription: Many people with allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms. Very sensitive people may experience severe symptoms

plantDescription.season: Early winter to late spring (most species)
plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves can appear as two types of needles; small sharp needles arranged in opposite pairs or whorls and scaly leaves. The cones look like berries.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Cedar and Cypress pollen. In addition, there may be a higher risk of food allergy to peach.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are alternate, long and narrow and the leaf margin is smooth.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Plantain (Plantago) pollen. In addition, there may be a higher risk for food allergies like melons, oranges, tomatoes, peanuts, soy, potato, and other legumes.

healthRecommendations: Pollen levels are very low right now. It's a great day to enjoy the outdoors!

indexInfo.indexDescription: Most people with allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms. Very sensitive people will experience severe symptoms

healthRecommendations: Avoid mowing the lawn and raking leaves.
When driving the car, close your windows and turn the air conditioning system to recirculation mode.
Keep your windows closed and turn on your air purifier or air conditioning.
Consider staying indoors during the peak pollen hours (morning and early afternoon).
Make sure to use an air purifier with HEPA filter in your home, especially in your bedroom. Don't forget to perform regular filter maintenance checks.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialColors: Leaves are golden, orange, red, and pink.
plantDescription.specialShapes: Forked trunk. The leaves are oppositely arranged, usually palmate and lobed, but can also be pinnately compound or trifoliate, with a smooth or serrated margin.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Plane tree pollen.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.season: Two distinct seasons, late winter to early spring, and late summer to fall (species dependent)
plantDescription.specialShapes: The leaves are alternate, obovate with a pointed tip, usually a lopsided base, and serrated margins.
plantDescription.crossReaction: There is no known cross-allergies related to elm.

indexInfo.indexDescription: People with very high allergy to pollen are likely to experience symptoms

plantDescription.specialColors: The bark is yellowish-green and smooth on young trees but grayish-brown and deeply furrowed with scaly ridges in maturity.
plantDescription.specialShapes: Cottonwood leaves are alternate and triangular. The trees produce white seeds that look like cotton. These seeds appear after the pollen season.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Birch, Oak, Hazel or Alder.

indexInfo.indexDescription: Pollen levels are very low and are not likely to trigger allergic reactions

plantDescription.specialColors: The bark is usually whitish-gray, silver, or sometimes red.
plantDescription.specialShapes: Birch leaves are often triangular with jagged edges. The bark on most birch trees has horizontal dark streaks that look like scoring. Birch tree bark is also well-known for its paper-like texture and peeling nature.
plantDescription.crossReaction: Alder, Hazel, Hornbeam, Beech, Willow, and Oak pollen. In addition, there may be a higher risk for food allergies like hazelnuts, almonds, peanuts, pears, apples, cherries and carrots.
